item.title: Simple Linear Regression
item.description:
Although a straightforward procedure, simple linear regression captures some key ideas about model fitting. Let’s consider $ x \in \mathbb{R} \rightarrow y \in \mathbb{R} $ and one is given pairwise data $(y_i,x_i)$. The relationship we assume between $x$ and $y$ is a linear one, yielding a simple model,

$$ \begin{equation} y=w_0 + w_1 x, \label{eq:lin} \end{equation} $$

where the $w_i \in \mathbb{R}$. Geometrically, we are assuming that scaling an $x$ by $w_1$ and then translating by $w_0$ gets you a $y$. At the risk of being pedantic, one can also express \eqref{eq:lin} as,

Uzair Hussain

✉️ : ughussain@gmail.com

👋 About me

I am a researcher with a decade of experience in tackling complex problems ranging from advanced physics simulations to using AI to image the brain and predict its neuronal activity. My expertise, honed through a PhD in theoretical physics and work in medical imaging, neuroscience, and AI, spans a broad spectrum of skills. I am a fast-learner, creative, knowledgeable, and have a profound passion for uncovering insights from data.
